text: my name is Norah Judy and I'm a 22 year
old Muslim American Libyan journalist
based in the Washington DC area and I
also travel as a motivational speaker so
people ask why playboy and I kind of say
why not I don't know why we're going to
sit there and constantly say well we
want people to understand what Muslim
American women are actually like but
we're only going to share that with
certain people no like my message is the
same I didn't compromise anything and I
think it's important to have that on the
grounds and on on a territory where they
were known for objectifying women or
sexualizing women but at the same time
like if my message is to combat the
objectification and combat the sexual
ization of women in our society then
what better way to share that message
and kind of put it in people's faces
than on the frontlines of where people
are known to do that
so there has been a lot of negative
reaction from the Middle East in terms
of my Playboy piece and I think the
first and foremost reason is that
because the website unfortunately is
banned in a lot of countries so people
are getting to read the interview my
message stems from where I was when I
was a lot younger and I was struggling
with my identity during high school I
was kind of going through side entity
crisis and I just couldn't figure myself
out and I was like hey I need to figure
out a way where I can finally find out
who I am as a Muslim American and how
those two fit together and how it
actually works
and so I impulsively ended up putting on
the hijab and so I wore it as a way to
reclaim my power and as soon as I did I
started working in journalism I got my
first job at a newspaper when you're out
in the street and you're trying to talk
to people sometimes people won't talk to
you or they'll comment about your hijab
or it might be a little bit harder to
get a job but then I quickly learned
that well I don't want to work at a
place that wouldn't want you to be
yourself anyway but the plus side and
the positive is that people know that
Muslim women are often misrepresented in
media today and so when you're
approaching a story that's a little bit
sensitive you can share that with them
you can be like listen like I know what
it's like and so you can trust me with
this story and that has been the most
room
this is a building that is covered in
medical records right now I'm pretty
much doing everything that I love I get
to tell stories around the country and
around the world that I care about that
I think are very important
I don't read the negativity and I focus
on posit and I focus on what's next
